Award.AwardTitle: Scholarship Program for Women in Chemical Engineering

Directorate.LongName: Direct For Education and Human Resources

Award.AbstractNarration: The goal of this S-STEM program is to increase the number of women in Chemical Engineering at the University of Illinois-Chicago over the next five years. Understanding how high school students make career choices and why they do not choose engineering is critical to attracting more women into Chemical Engineering. Recent studies show that women make career choices primarily based on the positive contributions a profession makes to society. Therefore, the project emphasizes the important contributions that chemical engineers make to society, such as developing alternate fuels to address energy shortages, environmental cleanup, and conserving water and water purification. A recent study has shown that being connected can play an important role in shaping students' identity as engineers, which in turn leads to higher retention. Therefore, the program ensures that prospective and enrolled students have face-to-face interactions and working relationships with practicing engineers. The program also maintains close relationships with alumni in local chemical industries who help in activities ranging from recruiting, career mentoring, providing internships, to consulting/judging senior design projects. The scholarships provided under the S-STEM program enable the enrollment and retention of 50 academically-talented, financially-needy students into the field of chemical engineering.

POR.DRECONTENT:
Project Outcomes Report

NSF Award 1060198: Scholarship Program for Women in Chemical Engineering

The main goal of this project was to significantly increase the representation of women (1) in the Chemical Engineering (ChE) Undergraduate Program over the next five years at the University of Illinois at Chicago (UIC) and (2) among ChE graduates. This goal stemmed from a self-study analysis of recent enrollment and retention trends in the department (preceding submission of the proposal). Specific objectives were: (1) To increase the opportunities for women among UIC Chemical Engineering undergraduates, (2) To enhance the undergraduate experience for S-STEM ChemE scholars via targeted mentoring and research / education / outreach projects, and (3) To form among our ChemE Scholars a sense of professional identity within the ChE profession during their undergraduate studies.

Need-based scholarships of approximately $5,000 per year were offered to all FAFSA-eligible students (women and men), to increase the percentage of admitted students matriculating into the ChE program. The scholarship incentive approach and promotion was formulated in view of social science research on the appeal of societal-benefits aspects of the ChE field and careers especially among women students. We employed a holistic approach to student recruiting: hosting student/parent events at UIC, partnering with school and student outreach efforts of the UIC Women in Science and Engineering (WISE) Program and the Admissions Office, pre-college student symposia at AIChE Midwest Regional Conferences co-sponsored with the Chicago Section of the American Institute of Chemical Engineers, local radio advertisements, and publicity picked up from a few press reports. Overall, 59 students received S-STEM scholarship support, ranging from 1-5 years depending on matriculation date and ongoing FAFSA need determination.

 INTELLECTUAL MERIT

A variety of project opportunities were piloted for the ChemE Scholar to enrich learning beyond the classroom, from which feedback was used to iterate and improve the program. Preoccupation with courses and grades did leave some students with little time to participate. Our final approach combined students of different years (freshmen through senior) into Cross-Cohort Mentoring Clusters (CCMC), with regular guided discussion groups on professionally relevant topics of chemical process safety and engineering ethics and also included meeting with departmental alumni and other practicing engineers. This was particularly well received by the students. Based upon this experience, and in his new role as Associate Dean for Undergraduate Affairs, the PI is currently working to expand the CCMC opportunity more broadly within the Engineering College as a whole.

 BROADER IMPACTS

The enrollment yield among women students had an overall upward trend. The last (fourth) cohort of 20 incoming S-STEM students included 48% women and 43% minorities. These figures contribute to bringing up the corresponding percentages in our undergraduate body. Both absolute number and percentage of women (1) applicants, (2) admits and (3) intent-to-enrolls are currently at all-time highs and have been monotonically increasing except for a dip in percentage of women in 2014. Amid a trend of increasing yield for admissions (with increasing selectivity reflected by rising ACT scores in the College of Engineering), the percentage yield among women went from behind men to pull ahead. While the yield for women trails that for men, women ChE admits have now nearly closed the gap, which speaks to a main goal of the project. Thus far 21 ChemE Scholars have graduated with their bachelor’s degrees (or will graduate after fall 2017 semester). 16 students remain active and making good degree progress.
